reviewText:
I'm reluctant to give this a bad review, because the artistic quality of the writing, visuals, music, etc. is quite high. Still, the experience as a whole leaves a tremendous amount to be desired. Here are the things that really come up short for me:

1. The Combat

It doesn't feel like there was a comprehensive vision for this. The game simply vomits enemies and makes them run towards you. There is no real enemy AI from what I can tell. This means that combat isn't particularly interesting to begin with, quickly becomes very repetitive, and despite how the game is marketed, combat is definitely its core loop.

2. The Polish

Scenes often smash cut from one to another super abruptly, with no fades or other transitions of any kind. The multiplayer is, as others have said, simply busted. There are just a lot of these kinds of little(?) details that make the game feel unfinished and rushed out the door. They say you gotta do the first 90% of a project and then the second 90% - Moon Hunters often feels like that second 90% fell by the wayside.

3. Narrative Structure

While the quality of the writing is quite good, the way that the story and characters are presented is a pretty hot mess. I understand what the game is trying to do in terms of allowing you to work out the story through multiple playthroughs (FWIW, I've been through the game five times) but in practice it doesn't function well. Character prologues would help, a little more linearity on initial playthroughs might help, there are a lot of things that could be done... Moon Hunters simply throws you into deep water without any real sense of how to swim.

There is a really great game somewhere in here, and a lot of the pieces are already in place, but so much of it just comes off as half-baked and barely-there. If this was in early access and coming to consoles a year from now, I'd say god bless - but it seems like Kitfox believes this is a fully-finished, ready-for-market game.

I can't see how you can play this, eyes open, and believe that.

reviewText:
At first it just seemed like a short little indie game without much on its bones.

Then you realize that the game is meant to be played several times over using different characters, while exploring the world to unlock more of the world to explore on your next playthrough.

After realizing this I was able to get into the game much more, knowing that I could explore the things I missed or failed to encounter on my next playthrough. This dynamic way of playing is new and fresh in my opinion. It allows the player to be flexible in terms of their time investment, whether that be a large investment or small.

I want to compliment the art direction of this game. I have seen a lot of harsh comments in other places that the game is ugly looking. However my opinion is that the game is the complete opposite of ugly. It is in fact quite beautiful, especially when you factor in all the different settings, towns, enemies etc. are all quite unique as well as make use of a wonderful range of pastel colours throughout the world. Scenes look like pixelated watercolour paintings.

Gameplay wise it actually is like a diablo/zelda style. Its not nearly as deep as diablo though so don't expect that. Its a very light rpg. Unfortunately the game is really easy. This in my opinion is the game biggest flaw and they really need to improve the AI of enemies because once you understand the mix of your abilities and start gaining modifiers and skill ups, you become super OP. The reason to keep coming back to to discover the world and all the unlockables (places to see, things to do, new classes, new pathways) however if the game was more challenging that those things wouldn't be such a cake walk to find.

Definitely buy this, once you indulge deeper into the games systems they grab a hold of you and make you want more. The world of Moon Hunters is compelling and definitely draws interest, but the level of challenge is fairly low. Nothing a few AI and blanacing twaeks wouldnt fix.

Let me explain this rating: I would recommend the experience of MH, not the game itself.

The value of MH is learning from its mistakes of trying to develop a narrative through mechanics. As someone who likes rogue-lite games yet craves for more storytelling, the idea of uncovering/shaping the story through replay-value is a novelty I can admire.

It's no masterpiece nor a new benchmark for rogue-lites; it's something of a failed experiment. That's how I'd explain my apprecation for the game.

So if you're looking for the next Binding of Isaac, FTL or a cooperative rogue-lite with lots of complexities, then this game is definitely not for you. And even if you like the idea behind MH you may not enjoy it for its flaws.

The 5-Day Adventure
A single game of MH can last you anywhere from 20 mins to just over an hour (alone). There are several contributions to the game's length: Exploring new areas/towns for the first time, combat, the game's structure and backtracking.

Each game of MH gives you five days before the final boss. The map is procedurally generated with special events. (Some have to be unlocked beforehand.) You'll never explore the full map because you can only visit one region per day. However, exploring towns or unique locales will not take a day away. You can also go in any direction.

The strangest thing about this system is you'll wonder how much padding is there in such a short game.

Some areas may be very small with several interactions. Others will have you in these huge empty regions with one or two interactions at most, littered with enemies. Some interacted characters/objects will tell you the solution--You need to be more PATIENT!"--while others won't give you a clue on how to access them.

reviewText:
Moon Hunters definitely feels like something a bit special. A gorgeous melding of co-op ARPG and emergent storytelling. With choices that genuinely shape your character and the world (or rather the heavens) around you.

Pitched as a co-operative action personality test RPG" it does have all those traditional RPG elements you might expect to find - Assorted class specific heroes with their own unique abilities. Character leveling and ability upgrades. And enemies (and cacti) that explode into loot if you hit them hard enough. But where the game really shines is in how it feels different each time you play.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lb3gbs07yug

You play as one of 6 heroes (4 starter classes with two more unlockable characters that can be found in game) whose quest is to find out why the Moon Goddess has vanished from the land. What's more you only have 3 days to do so.

As you travel across the procedurally generated world you come across random characters & objects and the way you react and interact with them not only changes your personality traits but also unlocks new characters
recommended:
villages and even familiars that can play alongside you. Though more importantly it helps write the legend of your greatest feats and failures in the stars above.

Each playthrough is about an hour long is definitely designed to be played with friends but more importantly to be played multiple times in order to unlock everything.

Admittedly the game is not perfect. I have come across a couple of minor bugs here and there (character names not appearing properly or hero skins changing mid conversation). The enemy AI can easily get caught on objects. And whilst there is a ton of content to explore the game is not infinitely replayable as you will soon get used to the various environments and start skipping encounters you've already made.

That said I wholeheartedly recommend giving Moon Hunters a go. A fun adventure on your own but even better with friends."

I backed this game on Kickstarter and was not disapointed.

Yes, a playthrough of Moonhunters is short (around an hour), but what people don't seem to understand is that the game is meant to be played many, many times. Each time not only is the map configured differently, but what you find in each tile is also different. Sometimes you'll have a playthrough where you encounter big sprawling mountains and gain a lot of wealth, while other times you'll be in small forests and are just scraping up enough cash to get by. Maybe you'll just play a runthrough to try a new build or character, or maybe you want to try and find a secret area or complete your recipe book. The length shouldn't be looked at as a downside, especially if you are a completionist. I actually love the short gametime because I often invite friends over and do one or two, 4 player couch coop playthroughs. We like to go for different endings, or we try to find something interesting or unique.

Pros:
Gameplay
Couch Coop!!!!!!
Multiple Playthroughs
Music
Art

Cons:
Bugs(even after extensive beta testing the game still has many bugs)
Story - I love the premise of the story, the story elements that are present, and the character descriptions once you finish a playthrough, but there's nothing that really changes with the story on multiple playthroughs besides the endings. More narrative elements could really propel this game to greatness.

reviewText: Moon Hunters is a procedural mythology game about weaving stories, defining characters, fighting monsters, uncovering secrets, and telling tales. It's a lot of fun, looks beautiful, and has a gorgeous sound track.\n\nAs a little extra: Moon Hunters understands a lot about how to make procedural generation more meaningful. In most procedural RPGs, you come across little events or random encounters, and that's it. That feels underwhelming - it's a bit like being dealt a hand of cards. You might not have seen those cards in that combination before, but it doesn't make it special. Moon Hunters is a bit more like a tarot reading. The encounters you have become compiled into who your character is and what they're doing, and they become part of a little story about you. So you didn't just come across a chest with a thing in - because you were Patient, you meditated under a tree and understood more about your quest for vengeance. Or you didn't. Or you found a cat instead and that was way cuter.

TL;DR the devs care about their game and will do what they can to fix any issues you encounter with the game. All you need to do is take the time to contact them.

--

Honestly, there are plenty of reviews on the gameplay for this game, so I'm going to do something a little different and talk about my experience with the developers instead. I will of course say I greatly enjoy the gameplay and bite sized play sessions Moon Hunters has to offer before I start. Now moving on to the bulk of what I want to say...

I've had a wonderfully pleasant experience with the devs of this game. I'll preface this by saying as my current profession I work as a QA tester in videogames, for an outsource company rather than in house with an actual game company. So I have has plenty of experiences with different game developers across many different projects that have all varied in size. This is one of the few times I've reported an issue not as an employee but as a client. I really enjoyed Kit Fox's game Shattered Planet, so I was completely on board when this game came out. I bought it right away but didn't play until several days after release because I don't really play games on weekdays. I waited for the weekend. When the time came to play I was impressed by the beautiful visuald and simple, yet compelling gameplay. Before I could finish a full run, which takes around an hour or so depending on the class you play I ended up needing to close the game. This is where my problems started.

When I came back to the game 20 or so minutes later I was unable to load my save. I got caught in an endless loading screen. So I did what came natural as a QA tester. For about an hour I tried various troubleshooting methods to see if I could somehow get the game to load, but to no avail. I was extremely disheartened and took to the forums to see if others were having similar issues. There I found some threads where Tanya Short had personally replied to users having other issues, and supplied her e-mail for people with issues to send more information. Now, had this been a AAA company I probably would not have even bothered contacting them knowing my own experiences from work as well as the times in my leisure at home where I had encountered issues with games but never been given a reply by devs... but knowing these were Indie devs I decided to give it a shot. Who knows, maybe this issue had gone under their radar. I wrote to Tanya, being sure to attach my save in my first e-mail, and gave a brief summary of what happened leading up to me being unable to load the game. To my surprise within a few short hours she replied to me saying she had sent off my save to their programmer, Henk, and asking for my output log to see if they could gather more information about the issue from what was in it. It was the weekend, so it was extremely suspiring Tanya would take the time to contact me. I sent the output log and patiently waited for what would come next.

A couple days later I received an e-mail from Henk Boom. There was a save file attached. He told me he had managed to create a fix for my save personally, apologized for the inconvenience, and then said he was looking into a long term fix to prevent this issue from happening to other players. I was blown away by the care these devs had placed into delivering me a superior experience as a client. I hadn't received this kind of treatment with any other developer before. And sometimes at work the devs seem more upset than appreciative when we find issues, even though they're paying us to find them haha. These devs are truly passionate about their game. I had been disheartened and unmotivated to play the game again, even though each playthrough would be a short time investment, until this moment. So I finished the playthrough on the save Henk sent me, which was literally 5 minutes from the end of the game, and then I played more more.

reviewText:
Every now and again a game sneaks under your radar and really surprises you. For me, Moon Hunters is the latest game to do that to me. It is the second game developed and self-published by Montreal, Canada based developer Kitfox Games following the popular Shattered Lands turn-based strategy RPG from 2014. This time around, however, they have created a marvelous little adventure-RPG game that is sure to surprise many.

I can appreciate that this one wont be for everybody – two of the top three reviews for the game as of time of writing are well reasoned negative reviews – but for those who the game does appeal to, me for example, will discover a game with a fair amount of depth and that has been developed with replayability firmly in mind. In fact, the game almost demands that you replay the game almost to the point where it may as well be compared to some rogue-likes (different genres entirely, however).

A single playthrough of Moon Hunters will last you about an hour to an hour and a half but do keep in mind that the intention was for the long game to be played over maybe a dozen or so times with each and every individual playthrough building the game world further. In each playthrough the likelihood is that you will see about half a dozen different locations. You will not see the entire gameworld on a single playthrough. That’s simply impossible. Unfortunately, what the game classifies as a unique event can pop up on consecutive playthroughs. this is a bit of a downer but the game does provide you certain objectives that it expects you to complete each game. I found the objectives to be a positive but it does disguise that there is a perceived lack of overall content.

The biggest problem with the game at this point in time is that the single player game can be viewed as tough but because the game doesn’t scale – or if it does it doesn’t do a great job of it – the more players that you are able to add the easier the game will become. If you’re an average gamer playing with a couple of friends then it can prove to be a walk in the park. Conversely, if you’re a casual playing by yourself then chances are you will find the game to be a tough challenge. But from my time with the game every time you would normally have died you ‘crawl away to safety’ and lose your opals (the in game currency).

I found the combat to be borderline. There are class imbalances. Some of the classes make the combat feel far too easy – click a button and move and you’ll kill almost every mob quite easily. Then there are classes where combat feels ultra difficult. As a single player this was very apparent to me while the poor scaling made combat in multiplayer too easy. There aren’t any interesting combat mechanics and I genuinely feel that the devs missed a golden opportunity to make another fascinating component of the game. Even the traits aren’t as interesting as they could be with a number of them practically useless.

I’ve criticized the game without really explaining what I’ve liked about it. There really isn’t any one thing that made me enjoy the game. It’s definitely a combination of things. I really enjoyed the aesthetic and the presentation of the game. I found it to have high production values for a mid-priced indie game and for a studio that have only ever created one other game.  I quite appreciated the ways in which the story is told and narrated. I enjoyed the exploration even though it wasn’t quite as rewarding as what I would have liked. I enjoyed spending time playing this with friends even with the poor scaling – we were able to become immersed in the world together and that made for a lovely experience.

I enjoyed the game but I know that it’s not for everyone. I’d definitely pick this up for those who like the sound of the concept of the game and doubly so if you have friends or family to play with.

As a kickstarter backer, I can say that it was not what I was expecting but it was better than I imagined!

The game is essentially a roguelike that emphasizes on building a story over multiple playthroughs, and with procedural generation the game keeps you entertained with each playthrough being relatively different (though I can imagine that if you played long enough you would start seeing repeating situational occurrences). What I did enjoy the most about the game is that your choices affect your character's traits, allowing you to interact with certain objects and NPCs differently. While this can cause some discontent due to missing out on some interesting dialogue or a chance to gain a companion/pet because your character did not have the appropriate traits, this is an incentive to play again and make different choices to gain access to things you have missed out on in previous playthoughs.

Overall, the writing is fun to read, the art is aesthetically pleasing, the game sounds great, and the gameplay is solid!

If you are a single player gamer, don't be discouraged! Despite being advertised as a multiplayer game, it is just as fun playing by yourself, as there is more than enough content to keep you entertained. Though I should note that unless you are playing a DPS class, it would be relatively difficult playing on your own. Now, I am not saying that you would not be able to play as the other classes, but it would most certainly be challenging.

I recommend this game if you are looking to have short bursts of fun (alone or with friends) that can be picked up whenever you like.

reviewText:
There are a lot of things to like about Moon Hunters. The game is fun to play. If you like 2D action/adventure games, like Zelda or Diablo, I think you will have a lot of fun with the game. The controls are pretty simple but are responsive. The game works better as a co-op game but you can still have fun with the game in single player. Moon Hunters probably works best in group settings where some of the players aren't experienced gamers since the game is pretty easy overall.

The story is interesting and I like that every decision you make has an effect on gameplay as well as the ending. Each decision you make gives you stat boosts that help you in the game. When you finish the game you also get a little story about your journey telling the legend of your hero. This legend gives you details about what happened to your hero after your journey. Combine this with great music and good graphics and Moon Hunters creates an engaging environment.

The biggest problem with the game is that each game is quite short (30 minutes to one and a half hours). This means you will quickly start running into repeated material. While the worlds appear to be randomly generated, the events that you encounter start to repeat themselves quite a bit. A good example is that the final boss of the game seems to always be the same (unless I have yet to find events that change the final boss battle). While this doesn't ruin the game, it keeps it from being as good as it could have been.

If you like 2D action/adventure games you should enjoy Moon Hunters. If you want to fully explore the game's world you can get quite a bit out of the game. If you don't like to repeat a lot of material though you may not get as much out of the game as you were expecting.

So, I kinda love this game.

The character designs, the art, the setting, the (gradually unfolding) narrative, the way the systems all interlock together into a coherent whole...

...love it.

I don't know what other games to compare it to. There are touches of Diablo here, touches of Majora's Mask, maybe a few other action-RPGS -- but the sum total is like nothing else.

You play the same 5 days, over and over, as different heroes, and gradually alter what happened across those days. The story is an exploration of the intersection of philosophies - moon/goddess worshippers are being encroached upon by sun/god worshippers, and the result has some very unexpected bends and turns as the tale unfolds.

Kitfox is supporting the game, and is a delight. I can't wait to see what they add, and how they respond to the audience response.

It ain't perfect - it's got some glitchy AI in some spots, and some of the balance issues always present in an autogenerated system with a power progression are present here... but there's nothing that interferes with the fun too much.

It's great. I just love the ♥♥♥♥ out of it.

reviewText:
Moon Hunters is a gorgeous co-op action rpg that brings a unique narrative twist to the formula.  I've included my thoughts in video form as well here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w8furYQuPVY

Moon Hunters sets out to shake up the typical action RPG formula with an interesting take on narrative structure.  While there are a few missteps along the way, it largely succeeds in creating a meaningful and memorable experience.

You (and up to 3 partners) take the role of 1 of 6 heroes, setting out to explore the mysteries of the world and ultimately to stop the Sun Cult from seizing control of the populace.  Along the way you'll meet a variety of characters, shape the personality of your character, and leave a lasting impact on the world.

The most important hook of Moon Hunters to note is that it is a game entirely designed around the notion of numerous playthroughs. A single 'playthrough' can be completed in as little as ~40 minutes, but each playthrough has the potential to unlock new features, new areas, and otherwise expand the world.  Each completed playthrough (whether successful or not) leaves a lasting memory of your character in the world's mythos, with literal statues built in their honor.  Reflecting upon these statues will give you a summary of their past exploits as well as a statistical bonus.

Each playthrough consists of 3 'days' in somewhat of a Majora's Mask style.  While it's possible to discover the final boss ahead of time, you will be forced into final combat at the end of the 3rd day.  As a result, you'll only be able to explore a small handful of locations each time.  Locations are somewhat randomly generated, though towns and special areas are static, allowing for a level of strategy and planning.  Between each area you're given the opportunity to camp.  In camp you can meet up again with NPCs you encountered during the day or partake in one of the many activities (including a rudimentary cooking system) for statistical bonuses.

Combat is serviceable, but not exceptionally deep.  However, a level of customization in purchasable skill upgrades will make playthroughs with the same characters potentially different each time.  Each character comes with 3 basic skills, typically in the form of a primary attack, a secondary attack/utility skill, and a defensive ability.  The Songweaver mixes this up a bit with the ability to combine 3 different song notes into combos of 2 (and sometimes 3) for a large variety of functions.

Basic enemies are not exceptionally smart, but characters are also not inherently very durable. Solo combat relies heavily on using your utility abilities to lockdown opponents in order to find safe openings to attack.  Some characters are easier than others; the Spellblade is a quick and deadly whirling dervish of melee combat, but the Occultist will need to use hit and run tactics in order to be successful.  Boss enemies are far more interesting (and visually impressive) encounters that require a fair amount of strategy to defeat.

Last but not least, the audio/visual style on display is exquisite.  The world is beautiful and colorful, the music/sound set the mood.  The atmosphere adds a lot to the experience and simply makes it a joy to play.

The game is not without flaws: World object hitboxes feel a little finicky/oversized at times and the rate at which new areas unlock for future playthroughs can be slow depending on your luck of finding new things in previous playthroughs.  All told, however, I've greatly enjoyed my time with the game thus far and it earns my recommendation.

(Full disclosure- I'm a friend of one of the developers!  But let me give you my honest opinion.)

Moon Hunters plays a bit like Diablo in the monster bashing sense, and a bit like Zelda in the world exploring sense.

The coolest innovation in Moon Hunters is the myth-building aspect.  As you play, you'll make choices that determine your character's traits.  These traits will unlock side quests, pets, encounters, and interactions with NPCs.  At the end of your run, your character's Myth is told to you, based on these traits.

The next coolest innovation becomes clear on multiple playthroughs!  Each playthrough you do will unlock new content for future playthroughs, expanding the world and the options every time you play, and revealing more and more of what is actually going on.

I haven't yet been able to get online multiplayer working yet, and the combat can be a bit easy at times- though I personally was sufficiently challenged a few times each playthrough.

Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who likes the idea of playing a solid couch-co-op game with their friends, exploring the world and learning more about it, and making entertaining character based decisions to find out what changes happen as a consequence.

reviewText:
Moon Hunters is a charming game with great art and music, interesting and novel narrative design, and very accessible gameplay. You really do have to play through the game a few times to start noticing the full extent of the narrative design, but thankfully individual playthroughs are miraculously short, 90 minutes at most - a great thing in a world of 60+ hour RPGs that nobody with a job and a family or relationship could easily approach. The first playthrough may seem a bit barebones, but the more you play, the more you'll notice the interconnectedness of your playthroughs, and the more you'll learn about the world you're playing in.

Combat reminds me most of Torchlight, though simpler and more straightforward. This is not an extremely mechanically challenging game and doesn't have skill trees of character customization - and I like that. It's primarily about the sense of being a character in a world, and figuring out both the world and its characters, which is all I wanted for it.

If there's anything I'd criticize, it would be a couple of issues in the UI. It doesn't seem to like me wanting to use the mouse, so I often find myself needing to press E to select something under my mouse that isn't responding to clicks, or using the WS keys to scroll through large text boxes that also don't respond to clicks on arrows, or the scroll wheel. It's also unclear exactly how the upgrades you buy from merchants apply - once you buy an upgrade it's said to be active, but not all merchants display the same upgrades, and there doesn't seem to be anywhere to see all the upgrades you have so far, if indeed they're persistent. A few other minor UI bugs have cropped up as well; hopefully these will be patched up soon.

I can see myself coming back for several playthroughs of Moon Hunters, because I still haven't figured out what happened to the Moon, visited all the tribes, or figured out how to talk to animals! I say get it, unless you're looking for something really difficult or really long.

reviewText:
I have been eagerly awaiting this game since I saw it on Kickstarter. Unfortunately, this is not the game that I was expecting.

The Pros:
The art design is amazing, the music is captivating, and the battle mechanics are interesting enough to keep me invested. I really enjoyed exploring the zones (although you are limited to how many zones you can actually explore before you reach the end of the game -- more on that below). Each class has a unique style and strategy for fighting enemies. I also enjoyed the character advancement system. It really gave me an incentive to explore and kill more monsters so that i could purchase new abilities with the opals that I collected from the game world.

The Cons:

=== No In-Game Tutorial ===
First off, the lack of direction in the game is annoying. There are no helpful tutorials or hints for new players. When I first started, I was uncertain what the hell I was even supposed to do. I ended up wandering around the first zone, nearly dying while trying to figure out how the game actually worked. The npc interaction is pretty vague, and and I had no idea how each choice even impacted my character. You really just blindly react to npc interactions and hope for the best. Eventually, I discovered that all of these interactions are recorded and help to shape how my character is perceived in the lore of the world. Unfortunately this really only comes to fruition upon completion of the game, detailng how your character is remembered by your ancestors.

=== Game Length ===
You have three in-game days until you reach the end of the story. This basically means that you get a handful of zones to explore before you must face the final boss. If you die in a zone, you immediately arrive at your camp and must rest, moving to the next day. This is very cumbersome approach to a game that has so much depth. I was expecting a longer, more driving narrative. I was expecting at least 40 hours of gameplay, side-quests, and an amazing RPG experience... What I discovered was that this game is basically a demo. The game that you can buy is really the first chapter or level of what it COULD have been.

=== Hit Point Recovery ===
The only way to restore HP is from camping, hoping that RNG blesses you with a heart after you defeat an enemy or destroy something in the game world, or by a specific class ability. It would have been nice to have some potions that you can equip and use with the press of a button.

Verdict:
Overall, this game is an interesting RPG, but worth no more than $5 in it's current state. reviewText:
Product received for free

Moon Hunters is the latest game from Kitfox Games, whose previous game Shattered Planet was a good, although simple, rogue-like. This time, they are reaching for the stars (pun intended) with a high concept action/adventure game built around replayability, I just wished the gameplay was as unique as the story.

Time to Kill:

The story of Moon Hunters takes place  in a strange land where the cults of the moon and sun are fighting each other. You find out one day that the moon has disappeared and the cult of the sun has branded you for death in five days. Each character belongs to different tribes (that you can select at the start,) as well as being completely different classes that determine how they play out over the course of a play.

A single play of Moon Hunters occurs over the five day period, where you'll explore the land to make your mark and ultimately decide the fate of the world. Each day gives you the chance to explore one hot spot full of enemies and items. You may also go to any villages and talk to the townsfolk there.

Making decisions will impact your personalty and affect your character's personal story, along with providing upgrades to certain attributes. During combat, defeated enemies will sometimes drop opals that can be sold for upgrades. Sometimes you'll fight bosses and discover hints and story lines to fill in the blanks about the world around you.

At the end of each day, you'll have the chance to camp and perform a task of your choosing to upgrade your stats further before starting the next day. At the end of the five day period, your character's actions and choices will be remembered by the people; leading to Moon Hunter's interesting progression model.

Reading the Stars:

Instead of going for a grand campaign or lengthy playthrough, Moon Hunters is about short, replayable  plays. At the end of the five days, the game ends, and all your actions will be processed and the game will unlock new content for you via the constellation system. For each new constellation that shows up, unlocks some kind of new content; be it costumes, new environments, characters and so on.

This is the perfect example of trophy room" achievement design: Giving the player a representation of their achievements and progress in the game. Moon Hunters is all about you replaying the game with different characters to see more of the story and make the game bigger in the process.

This kind of high concept take on story and replayability is something we normally don't see all that much from the action/adventure genre and gives Moon Hunters a different feel to it.

As you play
date: you'll unlock personality statuses that will give your character an end of cycle story epilogue. While all this sounds amazing
recommended:
the problem that I have with the game is a common one when story and mechanics clash.

A Limited Journey:

One of the hardest things to do when it comes to game design is when you have to balance a high concept or unique system with the basic foundation of your mechanics. It's very rare to see a game get both mechanics and storytelling 100% on the same page
hoursPlayed: and Moon Hunters is sadly not one of those games.\n\nWhen you have a game that's meant to be very replayable

votesHelpful: and the achievement system puts it over the top.\n\nThe problem with Moon Hunters is that for the interesting storyline and unlockable system
votesTotal: the base mechanics simply don't reach the same heights for several reasons. The first is that the game was built around co-op (with both local and online options.) Since you have multiple characters
votesFunny: each character has to be built from a basic foundation.\n\nEven though everyone has different abilities
commentsCount: the basic gameplay never grows or evolves; you're not going to find any game-changing upgrades. Given the five day playthrough cycle

it would have been interesting to have that factor into the character's Meta; allowing the player to impact things on the next cycle.

This kind of basic gameplay also extends into the enemy and level designs. Enemies fall into the "charge the player above all else" kind; being really easy for ranged characters and punishing for melee when the enemies can't be stunned or knocked back.

I like how there are hidden bosses to find and defeat

but you only get one chance per playthrough to fight them.

The levels were designed around wide open areas that points of interests could be placed into.

reviewText:
I'm giving Moon Hunters a provisional thumbs-up for its lofty ambitions, excellent art style and developer's promises for big improvements down the line, BUT this game does not feel like a finished product. It's in a place where I would expect a game to be if it was just entering early access.

My thoughts are based on playing the game in single-player mode as I have no friends. So:

The story bits you interact with are interesting and brushed with pathos, but they are too short, too sparse and the results of your choices are so murky and unpredictable that it barely feels like making a choice at all. You could flip a coin and the outcome would be equally uncertain.

Some story encounters are walled off to you unless you have a certain reputation, but there's no indicator that you might need that reputation beforehand, no way aside from blind luck to acquire that reputation even if if you had known you'd need it, and no reason to come back to that area if you acquire that reputation later. (Can you even go back to nodes you've already explored? I have not tried.) It's very frustrating to run into story elements you can't interact with when they are already so few and far between.

You spend a lot of time in combat and it just feels unpolished and bad. I may be being overly harsh here because I'm also playing a lot of Nuclear Throne, which is sublime and maybe not a fair comparison, but Moon Hunters suffers from unreliable hit detection, uneven enemy AI, and sadly unbalanced character abilities. Of the six available character types, I found only the Ritualist to be useful. Other characters either do laughable damage or get swarmed in melee.

The cooking system is pretty neat, although the benefits of using it seem scant outside of multiplayer.

Overall, Moon Hunters has big dreams that I applaud, but it's going to take a lot of improvement to get it to be what it seems to want to be: A rich journey of heroes who become legend not just by records of enemies slain, but by stories of paths chosen.

reviewText:
Moon Hunters certainly explores some interesting ideas. The game moves along at a good pace and you can expect to finish your first playthrough in 30-60 minutes. The art is nicely done and the music is excellent as well. I absolutely love the watercolors in the game. The character portraits are some of the best I've seen. The game constantly gives you choices and situations that are different every time. It was nice to learn about the world, cook, and shape the myth of my character. The fact that you restart the same story multiple times allows you to change your build every time without being overly invested.

That being said, the game isn't without its flaws. I played it coop and solo, and the coop game is much more fun. In solo mode the combat is more punishing and less interesting. The combat also feels a little clunky. The enemies pretty much strictly run at you, it would be nice if there was more variety in their movement. The character balance in Moon Hunters is very strange too, the spell-blade is a DPS storm and can annihilate the last boss in 5 seconds. The witch who is meant to be the strong character has a long cooldown on her attack and doesn't handle nearly as well. Depending which character you pick, expect a totally different (and sometimes unbalanced) experience.

I'm hopeful that Kitfox will iterate on these elements of the game with updates. I think Moon Hunters is worth spending some time with.

reviewText:
Rich with theme, this game is perfect for when you have a friend or two handy for an hour or so. It's not an epic 40 hour adventure story, it s short story that grows each time it's retold. It's a mix of playing for the stats as you learn what the various encounters do and playing for the fun of the narrative as you see just how your particular tale turns out this time. Lovely in so many ways, it's especially elegant in handling multiple players making choices without requiring consensus.

It could benefit from a more guided gating of the content (we stumbled on what looks like one of the most complex good endings a lot earlier than I'd like). It wouldn't hurt to add more content as well, but as complaints go, that's one of my preferred ones and it's by no means empty. There are a few minor bugs, but nothing that affects gameplay. Finally, there's no difficulty adjustment, and the game is a bit easier than dedicated gamers might want. Controllers and local co-op recommended.

Beautifully executed in so many ways, it provides a great mix of mechanics and experience in a short play time that you and your friends can return to again and again.

reviewText:
On launch day there were bugs that were deal breakers for some players.  For me in particular I had a game breaking issue when I tried to remap the keyboard and mouse keybindings.  The developers at Kitfox Games have since fixed a large number bugs and performance issues and even provided a full additional iteration on online multiplayer functionality.

Bugs at launch asside, MoonHunters is excellent in many ways.  It has very pretty visual artwork and music.  It has a play time that is shorter than a full FTL run, but like FTL you really don't experience the entirety of the game without replaying it quite a bit.  There are multiple endings and many locations impossible to experience in even a few playthroughs.  Each time you play your choices become a legacy for you that then gets written in the stars of the game, and your choices affect what happens to you in the game.  It's cool how in future playthroughs you see statues honoring your previous heros.

This game breaks the mold in many ways.  Mechanically there is no traditional level up system.  Instead your characters gradually gain stats and purchase abilities over the course of a playthrough.  Neither is there death in the traditional sense.  Rather, if your character dies you simply crawl away skipping the rest of that location and unable to gain any additional benefits from it.  In addition, all your choices in the game contribute to your character's personality. This then is factored into how you are able to interact with characters and events creating a noticably reactive world.

As you can likely see in the art this game is not set in a world of high fantasy or sci-fi, but rather one that is built around mythologies of ancient Mesopotamia and especially the Epic of Gilgamesh. This setting is a welcome breath of fresh air.

Visually the game looks amazing, somehow managing to use both pixel art sprites and detailed (what I think is considered) watercolor portraits and backgrounds.  Give the soundtrack a listen as well and you will find that it is nothing to sneeze at.

Multiplayer mode is very fun.  In single player mode I often go in and out of battles while maintaining max health.  Not to say that it's easy, you need to be focused and patient to do so, but on multiplayer I often find myself and teammates with less than half health and enjoying the game all the more for the tension it creates.

I consider this game well rounded.  I'm not sure how else to say it.  There's a lot of meat to it, like a lot of different aspects of the game are strong.  Many games fall short in one area or another, but this game has good art, music, story, choices, combat, and replayability.  It does all this without feeling like any of its strong points are borrowed from other games.

The mystery of the misssing Moon Goddess keeps me coming back right now, but even after I know the mystery I'm sure I will want to come back to enjoy smashing pots, flirting with npcs, and fighting all manner of strange beasts with my friends.
